newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkey to reach $5 bln sell-off target - minister.
newsitem.headline: Turkey to reach $5 bln sell-off target - minister.

text.p: Turkey will reach its target of $5 billion in privatisation revenues this year if there are no legal obstacles to sell offs, State Minister Ufuk Soylemez said on Monday.
"There is no reason at all not to reach this target as long as there are no legal problems," Soylemez told reporters.

Privatisation officials said the $5 billion did not include $3.5 billion expected to be raised from the sale of Turk Telekom, the keystone of Turkey's privatisation efforts, and revenue from the sale of power plants.
The Constitutional Court is to begin meeting on Tuesday to decide on an opposition request to cancel the sale of Telekom. A decision is expected within several days.
The government hopes to raise $3.5 billion from Telekom, the sale of which has already been halted three times by the court since 1993.
Soylemez said the first tranche of up to 15 percent of the telecommunications giant would be sold by the end of the year if the court gave the green light.
"I am hoping it will not be another cancellation," he said after the tender for the state-run Etibank.
Turkish textile firm Dogan Kumascilik put in the highest Etibank bid at $185 million but it was still to be approved by the High Board of Privatisation.
Soylemez, whose ministerial portfolio includes privatisation, said the board, headed by Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan, would rule on all outstanding bids by the end of January.
Turkish privatisation, which has garnered only $3 billion in the last 10 years, has gathered pace in recent months under Erbakan's Islamist-conservative government.
